Award.AwardTitle: RUI: A Program of Undergraduate Participation in CUORE and the Search for Neutrinoless Double Beta Decay
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neutrinos are amongst the most abundant particles in the Universe and yet we do not know many of their properties. For example, we do not know their absolute mass scale or their particle-antiparticle nature. Because of their abundance, even a small mass could have far-reaching consequences for understanding their role in the evolution of our Universe. Knowing if neutrinos are their own antiparticles could have implications in understanding the matter-antimatter asymmetry of our Universe. Neutrino-less double beta decay (NLDBD) experiments address these two fundamental questions. Double beta decay is a rare nuclear decay that has been measured in several nuclei when it is energetically favorable. Some nuclei are stable against ordinary beta decay but are unstable for double beta decay in which two neutrons in the nucleus are simultaneously converted to protons and two electrons are emitted. Double beta decay can proceed through several modes. The experimentally measured process, the two-neutrino mode in which two electron antineutrinos are also emitted, is completely described by known physics. NLDBD is an as-yet-undetected decay that involves no neutrinos in the final state and necessarily would indicate that neutrinos are their own antiparticle. The rate of such decays determines the scale for the effective neutrino mass.

CUORE (Cryogenic Underground Observatory for Rare Events) is an experiment to search for NLDBD in the isotope 130-Te and is currently being built at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory in Assergi, Italy. CUORE is an array of TeO2 crystals used as cryogenic bolometers for the purpose of particle detection. The crystals act as both the source and the absorbing calorimetric material. These kinds of detectors offer good energy resolution and efficiencies and are well-suited for NLDBD searches.

This award will enable the PI to continue to provide opportunities for undergraduate students to participate on the CUORE experiment. This will involve tasks such as monitoring the gluing of thermistors and heaters on the 988 crystals, helping to assemble the calibration system and elements of the electronics and assisting with cryostat alignment, with tests of the various subsystems of the detector and with cryostat cool down or warm up diagnostics. This will give students invaluable experience working with a cutting-edge physics experiment in a world-class underground laboratory.

An exciting sector of public outreach that Cal Poly will pursue is to develop an interactive visualization scheme for CUORE physics. This software will serve as a channel for the public to gain insight into the scientific process and explore the mysteries of particle physics. Through Cal Poly's Center for Excellence in Science and Mathematics Education they will help local teachers develop project-based-learning modules for high school physics courses that incorporate the underlying physics of CUORE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cal Poly physics professor Dr. Thomas Gutierrez is a member of an international collaboration called the Cryogenic Underground Observatory for Rare Events (CUORE).  They are searching for a forbidden nuclear decay called neutrinoless double-beta decay.  Discovery of the decay will help scientists understand why we live in a universe dominated by matter and not antimatter.  With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Gutierrez sends undergraduate students to the Laboratori Nazionali de Gran Sasso (LNGS) in Italy to work on the project, where the CUORE experiment and its earlier prototypes have all been located.  Dr. Gutierrez has had NSF funding to support undergraduate work on this and projects related to CUORE since 2007.

One of the deepest problems in physics is understanding why we live in a universe that's dominated by matter instead of antimatter.  Detecting a certain type of nuclear process called neutrinoless double-beta decay will help explain this puzzle.  Confounding the problem is that the decay violates lepton number conservation -- and no one has ever seen a violation of this well-established law of physics.  However, if the ghostly neutrino particle is its own antiparticle, current calculations estimate that neutrinoless double-beta decay might actually be possible, but has so-far eluded detection only because of its extreme rarity.  Current estimates indicate it might happen once in every hundred trillion universe lifetimes, an unimaginably long period of over a trillion, trillion years.  Nevertheless, with a sufficiently sensitive detector, scientists may be able to observe it, which is what CUORE is trying to do.  
The CUORE experiment consists of an array of about 1000 tellurium dioxide crystals, nearly a ton of material, cooled down to about 10 millikelvin just above absolute zero.  Each crystal is fitted with a device that measures minute temperature changes as particles interact with it; the colder the detector, the more sensitive it is to these interactions. If a specific rise in temperature is observed, it would indicate that neutrinoless double-beta decay had taken place.  
The experiment is housed in the underground facility at the LNGS, surrounded by about one kilometer of rock in every direction to shield it from cosmic rays.  Cosmic rays contaminate the signal and increase the background noise, thus decrease the sensitivity of the experiment.  Running since the spring of 2017, CUORE has not seen the decay as of late 2019, but it currently sets the best limits on the rate of the decay in the isotope tellurium-130.
The CUORE Collaboration is an international group of over 100 physicists from around the world, mainly from institutions in Italy, US, China, Spain, and France. Each summer, Cal Poly physics students become part of this team.  The students have the opportunity to interface with this international collaboration of scientists and work with some of the top people in the field. Professor Gutierrez?s students excel in this hands-on environment thanks to Cal Poly's Learn by Doing philosophy.
Undergraduate research opportunities such as this allow students to contribute to cutting-edge science and generate formative experiences for early careers, which ultimately contribute to a competent workforce regardless of their ultimate vocation. These opportunities also plant the seeds for the next generation of professional scientists. Moreover, international work such as traveling to the LNGS in Italy provides an opportunity for significant personal growth and encourages multiculturalism. There are many positive cultural, personal, and professional experiences awaiting a student who experiences research and travel of this nature. It gives breadth and context to both their physics knowledge and their undergraduate education. Work of this nature not only finds students with natural talents and empowers them to live up to their potential, but also develops and nurtures students with latent talents, allowing them to find their vocational path.
